content: We have had a minimum wage for some time now and everybody knows that it is not a very livable wage. But, it seems to me that Congress is going well out of its way to tax anything above $250k. In regard to the TARP bill and bonuses, HR 1586 sets the rate of tax at 90% of the lesser of: (1) the bonus amounts paid; or (2) the amount of such taxpayer's adjusted gross income exceeding $250,000 ($125,000 in the case of a married individual filing a separate return). And, of course, there is going to be much higher taxes on ANYBODY making over $250k, but what that rate is going to be is beyond me. Basically, not only have they set a minimum wage, now they are essentially enforcing a maximum wage. WTF???

content: We have had a minimum wage for some time now and everybody knows that it is not a very livable wage. But, it seems to me that Congress is going well out of its way to tax anything above $250k. In regard to the TARP bill and bonuses, HR 1586 sets the rate of tax at 90% of the lesser of: (1) the bonus amounts paid; or (2) the amount of such taxpayer's adjusted gross income exceeding $250,000 ($125,000 in the case of a married individual filing a separate return). And, of course, there is going to be much higher taxes on ANYBODY making over $250k, but what that rate is going to be is beyond me. Basically, not only have they set a minimum wage, now they are essentially enforcing a maximum wage. WTF???

content: We have had a minimum wage for some time now and everybody knows that it is not a very livable wage. But, it seems to me that Congress is going well out of its way to tax anything above $250k. In regard to the TARP bill and bonuses, HR 1586 sets the rate of tax at 90% of the lesser of: (1) the bonus amounts paid; or (2) the amount of such taxpayer's adjusted gross income exceeding $250,000 ($125,000 in the case of a married individual filing a separate return). And, of course, there is going to be much higher taxes on ANYBODY making over $250k, but what that rate is going to be is beyond me. Basically, not only have they set a minimum wage, now they are essentially enforcing a maximum wage. WTF???

content: quote: Originally posted by karlhungusjr: quote: precedence That is what this case will set and flow over to other areas. When this first came up I was uneasy for that reason too. But the more I've thought about it the more Ive decided that the "precedence" of Corporations that are deemed "too big to fail" and then taking public money while at the same time letting the executives and CEO's who ruined the company be rewarded is is much more dangerous than a targeted tax that came about because of a situation that's never happened before. There is absolutely no doubt that corporations need to be reigned in but to do so with a questionable law may not be the solution. Why give Congress the ability to rewrite reality to suit its own agenda? As a group they need to be 'taken to the woodshed' as much as the leadership at AIG.
